Black Violin, Wilmington

The two-time Grammy-nominated duo Black Violin are famous for mixing classical sounds with hip-hop. Instrumentalists Wil Baptiste and Kev Marcus have dropped popular tunes like "Stereotypes," "A Flat" and "Another Chance."

The Grand (818 N. Market St., Wilmington) at 8 p.m. Saturday, April 6. Tickets are $49-$164. Visit thegrandwilmington.org or call (302) 652-5577.

Katt Williams, Philadelphia

Katt Williams is arguably the hottest comedian of the year. He broke the internet in January when he appeared on Shannon Sharpe's "Club Shay Shay" podcast and took aim at several comedians including Kevin Hart. That episode has over 58 million on YouTube. The arena headliner used that publicity to his advantage as he continues his “The Dark Matter” tour.

The Liacouras Center (1776 N. Broad St., Philadelphia) at 7 p.m. Sunday, April 7. Tickets are $75 to $250-plus. Visit kattwilliamslive.com or (215) 204-2400.

Bad Bunny, Philadelphia

The only artist to stand between Taylor Swift having the album most streamed globally on Spotify in 2023 is rapper/singer Bad Bunny. The Puerto Rican superstar had the most-streamed album for the second straight year with "Un Verano Sin Ti," racking up over 4.5 billion streams globally. He'll bring his “Most Wanted Tour” to the City of Brotherly Love this spring.

Wells Fargo Center (3601 S. Broad St., Philadelphia) at 8 p.m. Friday, April 19. Tickets are $250-$855+. Visit mostwantedtour.com or call (215) 336-3600.

Kathleen Madigan, Wilmington

Is Sasquatch really or thing or nah? Kathleen Madigan shares the plan she'd use if she ever came across the elusive monster in her latest comedy special "Hunting Bigfoot," an hour of stand-up where she also focuses on her family, wine and the road.

The Grand (818 N. Market St., Wilmington) at 8 p.m. Saturday, April 20. Tickets are $49-$64. Visit thegrandwilmington.org or (302) 652-5577.

Dover NASCAR weekend in Fan Zone

During NASCAR weekend there's always a festival atmosphere at Dover Motor Speedway's Fan Zone, a place that often offers fun (and some free) activities for supporters.

Before this year’s tripleheader at the Monster Mile, the Fan Zone is delivering a lot of cool features like the World’s Largest Rubber Duck, NASCAR’s Kids Zone, White Lightning Bar + Arcade, performances from Tim Dugger and Friends, and the Amish Outlaws.

There’s also the Robocars (performers that are cars one minute and life-sized action figures the next), Mirror Men (strolling entertainers with shiny outfits and fancy moves), Dockdogs (a canine aquatics company featuring leaping dogs), bumper cars and much more.

ARCA Menards Series East drivers will be available for autographs on Friday at 2:15 p.m., followed by an autograph session with Xfinity Series drivers on Saturday at 9:45 a.m.

Dover Motor Speedway (1131 N. Dupont Highway, Dover). The Fan Zone opens at noon on Friday, April 26; and at 9 a.m. on both Saturday, April 27, and Sunday, April 28. To see the full schedule of events and for more info, visit dovermotorspeedway.com/fans/fan-zone.

WrestleMania 40, Philadelphia

The Super Bowl of professional wrestling is back in the City of Brotherly Love for the first time in 25 years with WrestleMania 40. This two-day event also marks WrestleMania's first time in the home of the Philadelphia Eagles.

Undisputed WWE Universal Champion Roman Reigns will put his belt on the line as he takes on the current Men's Royal Rumble champion Cody Rhodes. Meanwhile, Women’s Champion Iyo Sky will defend her belt against Bayley, winning the Women's Royal Rumble.

Plenty of other wrestlers will be on tap at Mania. One of the big draws to WrestleMania is the event has a history of bringing out surprise guests. Who might pop up this year? Only time will tell.

Lincoln Financial Field at 7:30 p.m. Saturday, April 6, and Sunday, April 7. Tickets combos for both days are $560 to $10,000+. Tickets for each night are $188 to $5,000+. Visit wwe.com.

Lewis Black, Wilmington

He often looks grumpy like a "don't stand on my lawn" kind of guy. That's become a trademark of the 75-year-old Lewis Black, who’ll stop by Delaware on his farewell tour: "Goodbye Yeller Brick Road, The Final Tour." The comedian was feisty about adjusting to the post-pandemic world in his 2023 comedy special "Tragically, I Need You."

The Grand (818 N. Market St., Wilmington) at 8 p.m. Thursday, May 2. Tickets are $61-$91. Visit thegrandwilmington.org or (302) 652-5577.

Dover Days Festival

One of Delaware's oldest and largest festivals is in the Capital City, Dover Days takes guests back to the Colonial era for two days.

The first day has fireworks, and the second offers a full festival and parade. Dover Days is known for Maypole dancing, balloon rides, historic re-enactments, artisans, games and food vendors, and more. This festival is rain or shine.

Near Leg Hall (411 Legislative Ave.) on Friday, May 3, and Saturday, May 4. More details TBA. visitdelawarevillages.com.

Point-To-Point, Winterthur

A fashion show, carnival and horse racing — these ingredients make up the 46th annual Winterthur Point-To-Point Steeplechase.

The yearly event raises money for the preservation and maintenance of the garden and estate at Winterthur. It features a parade of pups and carriages, steeple chase racing, vintage vehicles, raffles, community vendors and lots of family activities. But folks love to come out for tailgating to show off their extravagant outfits.

Winterthur (5105 Kennett Pike, Winterthur) from 10:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. Sunday, May 5. More details TBA. Visit winterthur.org or (302) 888-4600.

Temptations and The Four Tops, Wilmington

R&B greats The Temptations and The Four Tops both share throne rooms in the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame from delivering some of the most famous tunes in American music history.

The Temptations — which Billboard ranked as the Greatest R&B/Hip-Hop Artists of All Time (even ahead of Michael Jackson) — have charmed music lovers with classics like "My Girl," "Papa Was a Rollin' Stone" and "Treat Her Like a Lady."

Fellow Motown favorites The Four Tops are adored for songs such as "I Can't Help Myself (Sugar Pie, Honey Bunch)," "Reach Out I'll Be There" and "Aint No Woman."

The Grand (818 N. Market St., Wilmington) at 8 p.m. Thursday, May 9. Tickets are $79-$119. Visit thegrandwilmington.org or call (302) 652-5577.

Longwood Gardens Festival of Fountains, Kennett Square

One of the most popular attractions at the renowned Longwood Gardens is its annual Festival of Fountains. This ambitious display features over 1,700 jets that spin and dance, spouting water as high as 175 feet. Although photos of these fountains are captivating, they're extra charming when you see them in person.

This festival is also a good excuse to explore Longwood's sea of flowers.

Delaware destination:This Delaware attraction is a winner of the 2024 USA TODAY 10Best Readers’ Choice Awards

Timed tickets and membership reservations for the Festival of Fountains are available starting Monday, March 11.

Longwood Gardens (1001 Longwood Road, near Kennett Square, Pennsylvania) will host Festival of Fountains from Thursday, May 9, through Sunday, Sept. 29. For more info, visit longwoodgardens.org or (610) 388-1000.

Wilmington Flower Market

A lavish garden of fun and entertainment will blossom at a festive, three-day event that's a staple in northern Delaware. The 103rd annual Wilmington Flower Market has live music, rides, food, beer and (of course) flowers, and lots more. The event also has a habit of booking musical acts that have played Firefly.

Proceeds from the Flower Market benefit children’s charities in Delaware.

Rockford Park (2629 W. 19th St., Wilmington) from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Thursday, May 9; 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Friday, May 10; 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. Saturday, May 11. More details TBA. Visit wilmingtonflowermarket.org.

Broadway musical 'Little Women,' Wilmington

The audience will tag along for an adventure with the March sisters — Jo, Meg, Beth and Amy March — as they each strive to carve out their destinies in the Broadway musical "Little Women." The musical score tugs the heartstrings with themes of personal discovery, heartbreak, hope and everlasting love, the melodies of a young America discovering itself.

The Playhouse on Rodney Square (1007 N. Market St., Wilmington) at 8 p.m. Thursday, May 9; 8 p.m. Friday, May 10; 2 and 8 p.m., Saturday, May 11; 2 p.m. Sunday, May 12. Tickets are $50-$109. Visit thegrandwilmington.org or (302) 888-0200.

Holy Trinity Greek Festival, Wilmington

Have you heard about thousands of people hanging out on Broom Street in Wilmington, with folks dancing and singing, as the scent of fresh gyros kissed their noses?

Well, that isn't mythology. It's a tradition at the Holy Trinity Greek Festival. The event is the largest Greek Festival in the Mid-Atlantic region, and the only one in Delaware, per the festival’s Facebook page. The Greek Festival returns for six delicious days of fun in late spring.

Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church (808 N. Broom St., Wilmington) from Monday June 3 to Saturday, June 8. Festivals times each day are 11 a.m. to 11 p.m. Visit Facebook.com/WilmGreekFest or greekfestde.com.

St. Anthony's Italian Festival, Wilmington

This year the St. Anthony's Italian Festival celebrates 50 years of serving folks "la dolce vita," or the sweet life. The eight-day festival, branded as one of the largest Italian celebrations in the country, dishes up a variety of authentic and tasty cuisine.

The festival, which Joe Biden has attended, is sponsored by St. Anthony of Padua Parish; and the event is the primary fundraiser for St. Anthony of Padua Grade School in Wilmington.

St. Anthony's Italian Festival (901 N. Dupont St., Wilmington) from 4 to 10:30 p.m. Sunday, June 9; from 6 to 10:30 p.m. Monday, June 10 through Friday, June 14; from 4 to 10:30 p.m. Saturday, June 15; and from 2 to 6 p.m., Sunday, June 16. Visit sapde.org or (302) 421-3700.

Patti LaBelle and Gladys Knight, Selbyville

The Empress of Soul and the Queen of Soul are both coming to rock your socks off, even if your shoes are tied. Iconic singers Gladys Knight and Patti LaBelle are teaming up to deliver a dynamic night of music. Knight's songbook includes the hits "That's What Friends Are For," "Missing You" and "I Don't Want to Know" — while LaBelle is known for favorites like "On My Own," "If You Asked Me To" and "New Attitude."

Freeman Arts Pavilion (31806 Lake View Drive, near Selbyville) at 7 p.m. Thursday, June 6. For more info, visit freemanarts.org or (302) 436-3015.

Dover Comic Con

Since actions speak louder than words, you can tell everyone who your favorite anime is by cosplaying them at Dover Comic Con.

The free event is family-friendly and particularly good for folks who are new to cosplay and/or want to get a taste of what a comic convention is all about. (The con is also perfect for folks who love to people-watch.)

Lots of vendors and artisans sell wares and items at the convention.

There are usually cool vehicles on display like replicas of the Batmobile or "Jurassic Park" Jeep. Last summer, "Pokémon" fans went wild over a replica of the Pikabug car pulled up.

Near Leg Hall (411 Legislative Ave.) from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Saturday, June 8. Visit delmarvaevents.net.

Rolling Stones, Lincoln Financial Field

Folks can show off their moves like Jagger when The Rolling Stones stop by on their "Hackney Diamonds" tour in support of that new album. Fans can expect to hear the rock titans dish up their most popular songs ranging from “Start Me Up,” “Gimme Shelter,” “Jumpin’ Jack Flash,” “Satisfaction” and more, plus fan-favorite deep cuts and music from "Hackney Diamonds."

Lincoln Financial Field (One Lincoln Financial Field Way, Philadelphia) at 8 p.m. Tuesday, June 11. Tickets are $455 to $595+. Visit rollingstones.com.

The Cadillac Three, Dewey Beach

Don't be fooled, The Cadillac Three isn't just a country band. This trio from Nashville can get heavy with their brand of country rock. TC3 is beloved for their classics like "White Lightning," "The South" and "Tennessee Mojo." In late 2023 the band dropped their sixth studio album, "The Years Go Fast," which includes the single "Young and Hungry."

Bottle & Cork (1807 Highway One, Dewey Beach) at 8 p.m. Wednesday, June 19. Tickets are $35. Visit bottleandcork.com or (302) 227-7272.

If you have an interesting story idea, email lifestyle reporter Andre Lamar at alamar@gannett.com. Consider signing up for his weekly newsletter, DO Delaware, at delawareonline.com/newsletters.

search_result.title: Ciao, baby! Our guide to the Italian Festival
search_result.text:
Ken Mammarella

Special to The News Journal

St. Anthony of Padua’s 42nd annual Italian Festival brings a Renaissance theme – and food and drink, music, expressions of faith, rides, games, handicrafts and more food and drink – to Wilmington, Sunday through June 19.

The festival, which boasts the third biggest crowds of any Delaware event – 73,000, after Firefly’s 90,000 and the Delaware State Fair’s 300,000 – this year will add a centuries-old tradition to its beloved final day parade. Women of all ages will carry baskets of flowers on their heads during the Procession of Saints, which steps off at 2 p.m. June 19 and winds through the streets of Little Italy.

A sample, to the “Triumphal March” from “Aida,” is planned for the Gala Concert that opens the festival Sunday.

This tradition comes to Delaware from the Abruzzo town of Bucchianico.

“It’s a celebration of nature being reborn at the beginning of the summer season and a way to increase the cultural component of the festival,” Anthony Albence, a fourth-generation parishioner and a member of the festival’s steering committee for 10 years.

STORY: Opa! Our guide to the Wilmington Greek Festival

Linda Mionske and Roseann Detlefsen led the effort to create 75 baskets of silk flowers that vary in style and color.

Officials hope for a “reverent, spiritual and proud” effect by having women dress alike (black, white or Italian peasant outfit) and be in sync as they switch among carrying baskets on their heads and in their hands. (If the spirit moves, you still can get involved via ariannaalliance.org).

Cos'altro è nuovo? What else is new, you ask?

Scott Street is closing between Ninth and 10th streets, making room for a food court from Luigi & Giovanni of Newtown Square, Pennsylvania. The area will feature seats under five tents and a bar. The festival says the court’s 12 stations include “Italian fare not available in other areas at the festival – and often hard to come by at local Italian restaurants.”

That includes artisanal cheeses and meats, such as fior di latte mozzarella, soppressata and speck, Albence says.

Here’s our insider’s guide to making the most of the big IF:

Culture, food and fun: Those three tabs on www.stanthonysfestival.com spell out what draws perhaps those 73,000 people over eight days.

The festival, which benefits St. Anthony of Padua Grade School, culminates with a Feast Day Mass for St. Anthony, in Italian at 12:30 p.m. June 19, followed by the Procession of Saints. The church, a national historic landmark, will be lit up each night, and there are tours 5:30-8 p.m. Sunday, 6-8 p.m. Tuesday, Thursday and June 17 and 4:30-7:30 p.m. June 19. Participants in La Mia Piazza Italian Summer Camp will show off songs and skits at 3 p.m. June 18. A booth on dual Italian-American citizenship will be open at scattered times. Sales of devotional items benefit the Oblates of St. Francis de Sales.

Ceramics, biscotti jars, garden urns, jewelry and scarves were chosen for the festival marketplace to reflect the Renaissance’s “ethereal beauty” and “transformational spirit of this inspiring period.”

There are five major food areas, including indoors in the school and the new food court, and 10 bars. More popular items, such as spezzato, porkette and even the meatballs are known to sell out, he said.

Majestic Midways again brings 20 rides on the midway and Kiddie Land and a half-dozen games.

Contemporary music is every night on three outdoor stages. The Concerti sul Sagrato (Concerts in the Courtyard) feature traditional Italian music and contemporary music each evening at 7, on an outdoor stage or in the church.

The nitty-gritty: The festival is open 2-10:30 p.m. Sunday, 5:30-10:30 p.m. Monday-June 17 and 2-8:30 p.m. June 18-19. Admission is $5 for ages 14-61 and free for seniors over 61. Children under 14 get in free when accompanied by an adult (over 18). Weekly passes are $15 on-site.

Park it right here: The festival covers most of the territory between Lincoln and Howland streets and du Pont and 11th streets. Street parking might not be easy to find, particularly since residents of nearby streets are known – even though Wilmington doesn’t allow it – to reserve spots with lawn chairs or other items. “We do not actively go out and police the area residents who try and reserve their spots,” said city Police Department spokeswoman Sgt. Andrea Janvier. “However, we do make it clear that individuals can park in those spaces and move the objects blocking the space out of the way.”

That said, Albence urges parking at the Wilmington Riverfront and taking the festival shuttle.

Step right up for these deals: On Monday, a $30 Family Fun Night wristband will cover all rides. On Monday through Thursday, the Early Bird Special means all rides are one less ticket from 5:30-7 p.m. (and it’s less crowded, Albence said). A weekly pass is $12 online.

Now that’s Italian: Knowing these terms will make the festival more enjoyable.

• Sfilata dei Fiori: That’s the new Procession of Flowers accompanying the Procession of Saints (Festa Patronale). The floral addition is organized by the Alleanza per il Rinascimento degli’ Italiani Americani Nel Nord America, which generates the acronym ARIANNA and is translated as the Alliance for the Renaissance of Italian Americans in North America.

• A salumeria is an Italian delicatessen. Porkette served abbondanza is a stuffed roast pork sandwich. (My grandfather, who was born five miles from Bucchianico, often lectured young family members with that one word. I felt it meant both “don’t overeat” and “appreciate all the choice you have.”) If you’re stumble over other menu terms, someone’s always available to explain, Albence said.

• Per favore means “please,” and grazie means “thank you.” He said other good words to know are scusi (“sorry,” if you bump into someone), delizioso (“delicious”) and ciao (both “hello” and “goodbye”). And then there’s paesano. “It can mean a member of the family, a member of the parish family or a member of the festival family,” he said. “Everyone is a paesano the week of the festival.”

IF YOU GO

WHAT: St. Anthony’s 2016 Italian Festival, 901 N. Du Pont Street, Wilmington

WHEN: Sunday, June 12-Sunday, June 19

ADMISSION: $5 ages 14 - 61. Under 14 must by accompanied by parent or guardian 18 or older. 8-day passes $15, available at the site.

FOR MORE INFORMATION: www.stanthonysfestival.com

search_result.title: Wilmington's Holy Trinity Greek Festival adds extra day
search_result.text:
Six days and nights of gyros, neighborhood camaraderie and curbside lunch pickups will begin Monday for the 44th Holy Trinity Greek Festival in Wilmington.

Yes, you read that right.

The festival has added a day, starting on a Monday instead of Tuesday. (Oh, and they expanded curbside pickup, too.)

“We have found that there’s a great amount of demand for the festival on weekdays,” says George Rassias, parish president, who leans on an army of more than 100 volunteers for the festival each year. “So we’re going to give it a shot and see how our volunteers respond.

“We have no doubt the community will support an extra day, but for the volunteers at the parish, it’s a lot. Some of them are older, and it’s a lot of work to be on your feet for that many hours.”

The event at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church (808 N. Broom St.), a celebration of all things Greek from the food and dance to music, kicks off at 11 a.m. Monday.

But let’s face it, the food is the star.

From Monday through Saturday, June 8, you’ll find traditional Greek comfort food inside at the Hellenic Community Center (11 a.m. to 9:30 p.m.) with everything from pastichio ($10 Greek lasagna) and moussaka ($10 eggplant, potato and seasoned beef casserole) to dolmades ($5 stuffed grape leaves) and spanakopita ($6 spinach pie).

Other delicacies include chicken and orzo ($11), lamb and orzo ($18), tyropita ($6) and keftedes ($3).

There’s a free lunch shuttle from downtown Wilmington, running from Ninth and Market every 10 minutes from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. for those looking for a midday festival experience.

While a daytime visit might scratch that Greek food itch, nighttime is the right time for the full festival experience.

That’s when the outdoor food stands sling gyros ($9), calamari ($9) and souvlaki ($9) from 5 to 11 p.m. as the Philadelphia-based Greek orchestra Atlantis plays under the stars for its 32nd year at the festival.

Yes, the line will probably be long for outdoor food, but that’s almost part of the tradition at this point. In recent years, festival organizers have made a quick lunch pickup easier than ever. And for 2019, they are expanding it further.

Order online at greekfestde.com or by using their mobile app (GreekFest DE) and pick up curbside between 11 a.m. and 9 p.m. each day of the festival. (It previously stopped at 2 p.m.)

If the Greek fest puts you in festival mode, you might want to unbuckle that belt. St. Anthony’s Italian Festival in Wilmington kicks off immediately following Holy Trinity’s festival, running from Sunday, June 9, to Sunday, June 16.

Go to stanthonysfestival.com for a complete schedule.

Got a tip? Contact Ryan Cormier of The News Journal at rcormier@delawareonline.com or (302) 324-2863. Follow him on Facebook (@ryancormier), Twitter (@ryancormier) and Instagram (@ryancormier).

search_result.title: 20 years later: 12 details about Thomas Capano murder trial
search_result.text:
Sex. Politics. Secrets. Family. Murder.

Lurid elements swirling around the capital murder trial of wealthy Wilmington lawyer Thomas Capano captivated the public and made it one of the most sensational and dramatic court cases in Delaware history.

Twenty years ago on Jan. 17, 1999 — a frigid, Sunday morning — a jury found Capano guilty of killing 30-year-old Anne Marie Fahey, a scheduling secretary for then-Gov. Tom Carper.

It was one of very few first-degree U.S. murder cases that got a conviction even though there was no body, no weapon and no witness to the killing. The prosecution was led by Colm F. Connolly, a then 33-year-old assistant U.S. attorney who had never before tried a murder case.

The crime

Fahey, a single, insecure woman, was trying to end her secret relationship with 49-year-old Capano, a married man with four daughters, who also had other mistresses. After a night dining out in Philadelphia, Capano apparently shot Fahey at his rented home in Wilmington's Highlands neighborhood and jammed her body into a cooler.

Capano's two brothers Louis and Gerry helped him get rid of evidence and later testified against him. So did his other girlfriend, Deborah A. MacIntyre, who had bought a gun for her lover.

Gerry Capano said he took his older brother out onto his boat off the coast of New Jersey to dispose of the body. When the cooler wouldn't sink after firing a bullet into it, Tom Capano then dumped Fahey's body into the Atlantic Ocean. The cooler floated away and was later found by fishermen. They turned it over to authorities.

Fahey's remains and the gun have never been recovered.

The trial

During the trial, Connolly, the young, unflappable federal prosecutor who led the investigation, endured Capano's intense hatred, which included verbal attacks. At one point, Capano had even planned to put a hit on him.

Judge William Swain Lee sentenced Capano to death. It was later overturned. Capano died of a heart attack on Sept. 19, 2011, at age 61 at the Vaughn Correctional Center near Smyrna, where he was serving the life sentence.

The conviction was a stunning fall from grace for Capano, who had once counseled a Delaware governor and mayor and was the privileged, eldest son of a well-known Italian custom home builder.

From Fahey's disappearance on June 27, 1996, to Capano's conviction on Jan. 17, 1999, the public devoured every morsel of information uncovered. The trial, which took many twists and turns, spawned four books and a 2001 TV movie that starred Mark Harmon as Capano.

"I do believe this case served as a model for the principle that no one is above the law," said Connolly, who never tried a murder case again. He is now a U.S. District Court Judge.

"No matter how wealthy you are, no matter how well-connected you are, when the justice system works, you will pay the penalty for criminal actions," he said.

12 things we learned

On the 20th anniversary of Capano's arrest, News Journal reporters Patricia Talorico and Esteban Parra combed through records and evidence still in a Wilmington courthouse vault, and interviewed participants involved in the case.

Capano's attorneys Eugene J. Maurer Jr., Joseph S. Oteri, and Joseph A. Hurley; prosecutors Colm F. Connolly and Ferris W. Wharton; Judge William Swain Lee; key juror Erin Reilly Lee; former News Journal reporter Valerie Helmbreck; and Wilmington restaurateur Anthony Stella all shared with The News Journal exclusive, never-heard-before details about the case.

Here's a look back on what they said:

Jury initially split on Capano's guilt

Erin Reilly Lee, also known as Juror No. 8, said the first thing the jury did when they went in to deliberate was to take a vote.

Lee, 28 years old at the time, said the vote was half guilty, half not guilty.

But during deliberations, the jury's attention turned to the white, 40 1/2-gallon, Igloo cooler.

Capano had apparently stuffed the 5-foot-10-inch body of Fahey into the ice chest after she was shot to death at his home with a gun bought by MacIntyre.

In court testimony, Capano said he laid Fahey's body into the cooler on her side. He said he pushed her knees into a fetal position but insisted he broke no bones. Capano also said he had wrapped her body in a cotton blanket.

Lee, who was just a few inches shorter and weighed about the same as Fahey, agreed to climb into the 3-foot-8-inch hard-plastic cooler. Lee, who left her high heels on to compensate for Fahey's height, wanted to see if a body would fit.

As Lee squirmed inside the cooler, the lid wouldn't close. And that's when some of the jurors realized Fahey's bones might have been broken, or worse, to make the corpse fit.

The macabre situation, and the enormity of what had happened to Fahey, suddenly became overwhelming.

A traumatized Lee asked a bailiff to escort her to her hotel bedroom. The climb into the cooler-turned-casket helped convince Erin Reilly Lee and the jury of five other women and six men that Capano was a manipulative liar, a cold-blooded killer.

After crying in her hotel room, Lee said she spoke to Fahey: "I'm just so sorry. I'm so sorry that this happened to you."

'Killing a human being? That's the end of friendship'

Defense attorney Joseph A. Hurley vowed he'd take to his grave the reasons why he quit Capano's legal team six months before the October 1998 murder trial began.

But he didn't.

In November 2017, Hurley shared with The News Journal that he decided to quit during a moment of reflection and moral clarity while attending a funeral Mass at St. Helena's Catholic Church in Penny Hill.

Despite what many believed, Hurley said Capano never confessed to him that he murdered Fahey.

"I can only surmise that there was something making me feel like I was falling into an evil pit, and this conversation, if that's what you have with God, [went] 'Joe, you're not like this. You can't be this way, '" Hurley said.

"I think I was probably facing the reality [Capano] was, in fact, guilty of premeditated murder."

Hurley said he left the church, went to see Capano in prison and quit the defense team.

Hurley said he never saw Capano again.

"Killing a human being? No,” Hurley said. "That's the end of friendship."

Only in Delaware – Part I

Prosecutor Ferris Wharton and family members had some Only in Delaware encounters with the Capanos before and after the trial.

"I knew Capano, not well, just basically to say 'hello,'" said Wharton, now a Superior Court judge. "We weren't friends. He was the kind of person you would see at the check-out line at Acme."

"The longest conversation I had with him was in the dog park at Rockford Park. We each had black Labrador retrievers. He told me about Labrador retrievers. He talked like he knew all about them. He went on and on."

Wharton said not too long before Capano's arrest, he saw him while walking his dog down Wilmington's Delaware Avenue. Capano was coming out of a liquor store on Union Street.

"He said, 'Can I still say hello?' I go, 'Yeah, OK.'"

Wharton said, years later, family members had an encounter with a main witness from the trial.

"My brother's wife was driving near Brandywine Creek State Park and she hit some black ice and ran off the road. No damage or anything. She called my brother and he came out. This guy comes up with a pickup truck with a tow on it. He pulled their car out of the ditch. My brother wants to give him money. And the guy's refusing. My brother's insisting and the guy's still refusing.

"Finally, my brother said, 'Well, thank you. What's your name?'

And he said, 'Gerry Capano.'"

Dream Team became 'a nightmare'

Criminal defense lawyer Eugene J. Maurer Jr. was at first thrilled with the prospect of representing Capano.

Maurer said the excitement slowly ebbed as the case wore on.

"Having gotten a taste of what was to come in representing Mr. Capano," Maurer said he wanted to withdraw soon after Hurley, "but was concerned that the simultaneous withdrawal of both attorneys would have a deleterious impact on Tom's public posture."

Things quickly went from bad to worse, Maurer said, especially when Capano decided that his chances would be better by hiring an outsider from Boston, where he had attended school at Boston College.

"Joe Oteri arrived on the scene with a lot of bluster to assume the role of lead counsel at Tom's urging. We were later joined by a Florida attorney who had attended school with Tom and showed up uninvited at the prison, proceeding to convince Tom that he would be an invaluable part of the defense team," Maurer said.

Despite being called the "Dream Team," Maurer said "the defense in this case became a nightmare. [Attorney Charles] Oberly and I took a back seat as lead counsel Oteri orchestrated the weekly meetings with Tom at the prison where the two of them would try to out-manipulate the other."

Said Maurer: "Tom was an impossible client, pushing the envelope at all times and making the representation quite unpleasant. Ethical boundaries were of no consideration to him in formulating his defense strategy, as was demonstrated by the evidence at trial."

"Instead of a challenging and fulfilling professional experience, the representation of Tom Capano was one of the most depressing and disappointing professional experiences of my life," he said.

Taking a lawyer for a client: Bad mistake

Boston attorney Joseph S. Oteri, whose clients have included drug dealers, was referred to Capano in 1998.

Oteri's brash style became one of the trial's hallmarks, but he said the defense was full of challenges. "I made a bad mistake in taking a lawyer for a client."

Oteri said being Capano's attorney "didn't make me feel anything but pissed off because I kept saying, 'You're paying me an enormous fee and you're not listening to me. How stupid can you be?'"

Oteri said the trial "was not a very pleasant experience. The only good thing about it was Bill Lee. He was a good judge. He's a decent human being. He knows the law. He applies it without fear of favor. He takes no shit from anybody and he's a pleasure to work in front of."

He also added, "the two prosecutors were straight as arrows. They didn't take any cheap shots. They were very honorable men and they tried a hell of a case."

He 'thinks they are going to fall in love with him'

Judge William Swain Lee could not talk to the media during the trial or for years after. But the judge, now retired, shared several never-heard-before nuggets about the Capano trial in a November 2017 interview with The News Journal.

Lee said the jury selection was memorable.

"After the first two jurors had been picked, three straight selections involved single women in their mid- to late-20s. Attractive ladies. Under the circumstances, that wasn't what you expected the defense to be allowing," Lee said.

Anne Marie Fahey was a young, attractive woman.

"The defense attorneys called a sidebar, came up and wanted to go on record that all four of his attorneys had recommended dismissing these three jurors, but Capano insisted on seating them," Lee said.

"They wanted the record made clear that should not be a basis for questioning their competence during the proceedings."

"As we were leaving, Mr. Oteri, the lead defense attorney and certainly the most flamboyant of the group, said, 'Can I go off the record, Judge?'

"And I went, 'Sure. Off the record.'"

"Oteri said: 'The dumb son of a bitch thinks they are going to fall in love with him.'"

"And I think that was true," Lee said. "He thought he was going to be able to charm them."

Lee said he never knew Capano "personally, when he had the reputation of being a charming man, but in the setting in which I knew him, he was more rodent-like. He was a frightening, scary figure. There was nothing charming about him at all."

The reappearance of the cooler

The cooler Capano used for Fahey's body was discovered off Indian River Inlet, about 100 miles from where it had been thrown into the ocean.

Fishermen turned it over to authorities after reading about Capano's arrest in the newspaper. Lee said it it was astonishing that the cooler had been found.

"My reaction was Tom Capano should know there really is a God now. It's certainly stranger than fiction, the truth," Lee said.

Only in Delaware - Part II

Colm Connelly said the trial "was the ultimate professional experience I will ever have, and I was very young to have had it."

In another Only in Delaware moment, Connolly told The News Journal he once had a brief chat with Anne Marie Fahey while she worked for then-Gov. Tom Carper.

"I actually had spoken with her once on the phone, as it turns out. I was chairman of the Delaware Hospice Festival of Trees, an annual fundraiser, and we needed to schedule the governor to speak. I ended up scheduling it through Anne Marie. But I didn't know who she was other than that phone call."

And there was a very brief meeting with Capano well before the investigation

"I was a very junior prosecutor on a team of prosecutors who prosecuted Kermit Justice, who had been Delaware's Secretary of Transportation. [In 1992], Bill Carpenter, Bob Prettyman and I were on a conference call with Tom Capano who was, at that point, legal counsel to Mike Castle, then the governor. It had to do with the fact that Kermit Justice had been indicted [on several charges in connection with an FBI sting operation]. I didn't say a word during the conservation ... Other than that, I didn't know anything about him."

A meeting in Acme set things in motion

Connolly said on a July Fourth weekend in 1996 he was at the Acme Market on U.S. 202 when he ran into Judge Greg Sleet, then the U.S. Attorney and Connolly's boss.

"The lead story of The News Journal that day was President Clinton offered federal assistance [to find Anne Marie Fahey, who had not been seen since June 27]. Judge Greg Sleet and I laughed, because Greg Sleet was the U.S. attorney, so he was the chief federal law enforcement officer, and nobody had contacted him. If you were really going to get the feds involved, you would contact him," Connolly said.

"He said, 'Well, I'll call over to Wilmington, and we'll offer our services.' The next working day, July 8, the FBI called us."

Conversation with Capano 'reeked of manipulation and coercion'

Former News Journal reporter Valerie Helmbreck in the summer of 1996 received a phone call at her Hockessin home from Tom Capano.

Helmbreck had been working on stories about Fahey for weeks and calls to Capano’s lawyers asking for interviews had gone nowhere.

For about 90 minutes, Capano had an “off the record” conversation with Helmbreck that couldn't be used in a story.

Helmbreck said Capano was "trying to seduce me into seeing his vision of Anne Marie Fahey, seeing his version of reality. Only I wasn’t buying it. I was older, more secure, happily married, and frankly, I’d been played by better."

Helmbreck wrote in a November 2017 essay for The News Journal that the conversation "reeked of manipulation and coercion. It was a combination of little boy charm and school yard bullying, in equal measure."

At the end of the phone call, Capano agreed to an on-the-record interview. He never did the promised interview.

After his phone call, Capano parked his car at the end of the street where Helmbreck's daycare provider lived and waited for her to pass by.

"I never did figure out why, but I know it made me uncomfortable. I still find the memory chilling," she said.

Italian restaurant scene of out-of-courtroom encounters

Anthony J. Stella once owned a popular Italian eatery, L’Osteria Cucina Italiana, on Marsh Road in Penny Hill. It closed in December 2004.

When it was operating, the intimate Italian restaurant was visited by some of the big names on both sides of the Capano murder trial.

The restaurant also is mentioned in at least one letter Capano mistress Deborah MacIntyre wrote to Capano while he was in prison.

"A day or two before Tommy was arrested, the place was real busy and Tommy was standing at the bar. I knew what was going on, but played dumb," Stella wrote in a 2017 essay for The News Journal.

"When I greeted him, we talked about how crazy our lives were and he said, “I guess you’ve heard about me?”

"I said, 'No, what’s up?'

"He told me that he was a suspect in a murder case.

"I asked, 'Well, did you?'

"He responded, 'No.'

"We both laughed. I think he was arrested a couple of days later."

'I think it was suicide by food'

In 2006, Capano's death sentence was overturned. A life sentence was his punishment.

Years of confinement and isolation on death row had begun to take its toll. Capano, overweight with sallow skin and a wispy, white beard, no longer resembled the fit, polished, man-about-town he had once been.

"He had gained a massive amount of weight since the trial," Connolly said.

"He ate himself to death; there's no question about it," said Judge Lee, who never saw Capano again after sentencing him to death.

"His father died of a heart attack, he knew he had a heart condition. Once his appeals ran out, I think it was suicide by food," said Lee, who retired from the bench nine months after the trial.

search_result.title: 16 cool things - from festivals and concerts to experimental theater ...
search_result.text:
Visit South Jersey

Special to the Cherry Hill Courier-Post

If the rain ever stops, and even if it doesn't, there are a host of fun things to do in South Jersey.

Here are some ideas from Visit South Jersey to get you out and exploring the region, especially if the sun comes back out.

Incorruptible: A Dark Comedy of the Dark Ages. Sept. 13, 14, & 15 | Showtimes vary, The Ritz Theatre Company, Haddon Township. Welcome to Priseaux, France, 1250 AD, a miserable place where the Dark Ages still look pretty dark. The locals are looking forward to the Pope’s visit, which will surely encourage others to make the trek to their town and restore its former glory. That is, until a rival church claims to posses relics of Saint Foy and "their" bones are working miracles. All seems lost until the monks take a lesson from a larcenous minstrel, who teaches them a new way to pay old debts. Performing at The Ritz Theatre Company from now through Sept. 30.. Visit www.ritztheatreco.org/show/1975/

More:Play about Hurricane Sandy hits at a powerful time

More:New Jersey wine events to mark on your fall calendar

More:8 South Jersey apple orchards where fruit is ripe for the picking

Food Truck Friday. Friday, Sept. 14 | 5 PM - 8:30 PM, White Horse Winery, Hammonton. Start your weekend off right with food trucks and live music at White Horse Winery. White Horse Winery's live music performances are held in its tasting room or on their outdoor patio depending upon weather. This week's featured food truck is Baby Blue Rolling Kitchen and performing live is Sara James. Visit www.whitehorsewinery.com/

Noir: A Semi-Cinematic Thriller. Sept. 14, 15, & 16 | Showtimes vary, Eagle Theatre, Hammonton. Join The Eagle Theatre for a tantalizing glimpse into a day in the life of America's worst private detective, Jack Sloan. Filled with theatrical tricks of the trade, "Noir'' seamlessly blends live-action comedy with three dimensional cinematography, using up-to-the-minute technology to immerse the audience. You won't want to miss this Eagle Theatre Original World Premiere as it breaks down all barriers and paints a new mug on the face of mixed media.The show runs through Oct. 14..Visit www.eagletheatre.org/

Fall Craft Show. Saturday, Sept.15 | 9 AM - 4 PM, Uptown Pitman. Uptown Pitman’s Craft Shows have been a bi-annual event for over 40 years! The Fall Craft Show will be held in the main corridors of Pitman, along Broadway, Pitman, and Ballard Avenues. There will be over 350 vendors showcasing a variety of handcrafted goods. Shoppers can enjoy food trucks and specialities, as well as local businesses, restaurants, non-profits, and more. Visit uptownpitman.com/events/2018-craft-shows/

Delaware River Festival. Saturday, Sept. 15 | 10 AM - 4 PM, Wiggins Waterfront Park, Camden Waterfront. Come celebrate the mighty Delaware River with the Partnership for the Delaware Estuary (PDE) and the Alliance for Watershed Education (AWE)! For the first time, PDE’s Pennsylvania Coast Day and AWE’s River Days are coming together for a “coast to coast” experience. There will be educational fun for families, on-the-water activities, games and crafts for kids, live music, food and beer, fishing opportunities and more. Visit facebook.com/events/368882913622093/

WineFestNJ 2018. September 15 & 16 | 12 PM - 5 PM, Valenzano Winery, Shamong. Join Valenzano Winery for another year of great wine, bands and a huge selection of food trucks and dining options at WineFestNJ! There will be wine tastings from New Jersey's best wineries, four stages of music and entertainment, more than 70 local crafters and vendors, food options and more. Be sure to get your tickets in advance, this event sells out every year. Visit valenzanowine.com/event/winefest2018/

Bridgeton Crabfest/Riverfest. Saturday, September 15 | 1 PM - 6 PM, Downtown Bridgeton. Don’t miss the Bridgeton Crabfest/Riverfest this weekend! The Riverfest portion of the event will feature educational vendors and family-friendly attractions such as free face painting and a bouncy house, while the Crabfest portion of the event will feature delicious food, a beer garden, and more! Tickets are required. Visit squareup.com/store/bridgeton-main-street-association/

Outlaw Music Festival. Saturday, September 15 | 2 PM, BB&T Pavilion, Camden Waterfront. This lineup of musicians includes Willie Nelson & Family, Van Morrison, Tedeschi Trucks Band, Greensky Bluegrass, Lukas Nelson + Promise of the Real, and Particle Kid! Don't miss this amazing concert at the BB&T Pavilion.. Visit livenation.com/venues/14115/bb-t-pavilion

St. Anthony's Italian Festival. Saturday, September 15 | 2 PM - 10 PM, Downtown Glassboro. Join Glassboro for their St. Anthony's Italian Festival. There will be carnival games, live entertainment, beer gardens, pasta making demonstrations, wine stomping, and of course, Italian food. The festival offers a wide variety of delicious and authentic Italian food specialties. Experience a virtual tour of Italy during your visit by dining in various indoor and outdoor dining locations. Visit glassboro.org/italian-festival-2018/

Saturday Live Music Series. Saturday, September 15 | 6 PM - 9 PM, Sharrott Winery, Hammonton. Come enjoy wine and live music at Sharrott Winery. Live music will be in Sharrott's new tasting room with indoor and outdoor seating available. Wine tastings are $10 per person and include six samples of Sharrott's award-winning wines. They also have food options such as gourmet flatbreads from their new wine bar menu. Can't make it out? Don't worry, Sharrott Winery has live music performances every Sunday as well. Visit sharrottwinery.com/events/saturday-live-music-series-avi-wisnia-sept-15/

Wine & Music Series: Oldies Night. Saturday, September 15 | 7 PM - 10 PM, Summit City Winery, Glassboro. Things are always hopping at Summit City Winery during Oldies Night. Come by for a glass or two of wine and some oldies tunes from DJ Lou Costello. Complimentary wine pairing snacks will be provided and you may bring your own food. There is a $10 cover charge. Also don't miss Summit City's first ever University Jazz Series every Sunday from 4 to 7 p.m.. Visit summitcityfarms.com/events/#scheduled

Cowtown Rodeo. Saturday, September 15 | 7:30 PM, Cowtown Rodeo, Pilesgove. Started back in 1929, Cowtown Rodeo has stood the test of time, remaining true to the traditions of the Old West and bringing you a taste of western ranching. Cowtown Rodeo is the longest running weekly rodeo in the United States. Each week guests can enjoy seven pro-rodeo events including bull riding, bareback riding, and tie down roping, as well as a BBQ buffet. Visit cowtownrodeo.com/default.aspx

Vinyasa & Vino. Sunday, September 16 | 11 AM, Bellview Winery, Landsiville. Vinyasa and Vino is a monthly yoga program at Bellview Winery. Guests can enjoy one hour of Vinyasa (breath for breath flow) right next to the vineyard, guided by Joy Torres from Peace Love Yoga. This class is suitable for all levels and is beginner friendly. All you need to do is bring a yoga mat, a bottle of water, and a friend to enjoy your wine with. After the class ends, choose a wine to enjoy and unwind. Visit bellviewwinery.com/

Autumn with the Animals. Sunday, September 16 | 11 AM - 4 PM, Woodford Cedar Run Wildlife Refuge, Medford. Children and adults of all ages can enjoy Woodford Cedar Run Wildlife Refuge's wildlife programs, live music, nature hikes, child-friendly games, crafts, food, and fun all day long at Autumn with the Animals! There also will be face painting, marshmallow roasting by the fire, animal encounters, canoeing and more. This is a way for members and friends to reconnect with each other and the environment. Visit cedarrun.org/content/Visit_us/special_event.asp

Winter is Coming: Preparation & Preservation. Sunday, September 16 | 12 PM - 4 PM, Red Bank Battlefield Park, National Park. Are you curious about how colonial American's prepared their food for winter? Come by the Whitall House at Red Bank Battlefield Park for activities, tours and demonstrations where you can learn how the Whitall family would prepare their household for the harsh 18th century winters. Visit facebook.com/events/338429043332540/

Historic Smithville Mansion Tours. Sunday, September 16 | 1 PM - 4 PM, Smithville Mansion, Eastampton. The Historic Smithville Mansion tours are every Thursday and Sunday at 1, 2 and 3 p.m. Tours include a verbal history and tour of the Mansion and Gallery Annex. A tour donation of $8 for adults and $7 for seniors and students is requested. Visit www.smithvillemansion.org/

For more events, check out VisitSouthJersey.com

search_result.text:
Editor's note: This story has been updated to clarify what diseases different tick species transmit.

Ticks don't just hope you walk by so they can latch on.

They formally quest for a victim by crawling to the top of leafy vegetation all over Delaware. There, they wave their teeny arms in hopes of catching a ride to a delicious meal of blood.
